jgame.controller

Class TweenController

  • java.lang.Object
    • jgame.controller.TweenController
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Controller
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AlphaTween, MovementTween, RotationTween, ScaleTween, SizeTween

    public abstract class TweenController
extends java.lang.Object
implements Controller
    A controller that allows tweening between two states. Tweens can be chained with the chain(TweenController) method to allow consecutive tweening. Tweens also support the various types of interpolation as defined in the Interpolation enumeration.
    Author:
    William Chargin

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private int duration
      The total duration of the controller.
      private Interpolation interpolationType
      The type of interpolation used for this tween.
      private TweenController next
      The controller that will be attached after this one.
      private int tick
      The number of frames that have gone by since the controller began.
      private java.util.List<TweenController> with
      The list of tween controllers that will be run with (beginning at the same time as) this one.

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      TweenController(int duration)
      Creates the controller with the given duration and a linear interpolation type.
      TweenController(int duration, Interpolation interpolationType)
      Creates the controller with the given duration and interpolation type.

    • Method Detail

      • chain

        public void chain(java.util.List<TweenController> chain)
        Calls chain(TweenController) on all items in the given list. Note that any duplicate items will cause an IllegalArgumentException to be thrown, because an infinite loop will be created.
        Parameters:
        chain - the list of controllers to chain

      • chain

        public void chain(TweenController end)
           throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Adds the given controller to the end of the chain. If an infinite loop is detected, this method will fail and throw an exception.
        Parameters:
        end - the new end controller
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if an infinite loop is detected

      • chain

        public void chain(TweenController... chain)
        Calls chain(TweenController) on all given items. Note that any duplicate items will cause an IllegalArgumentException to be thrown, because an infinite loop will be created.
        Parameters:
        chain - the controllers to chain

      • controlObject

        public void controlObject(GObject target,
                          Context context)
        Description copied from interface: Controller
        Performs one iteration of controlling the specified object in the given context.
        Specified by:
        controlObject in interface Controller
        Parameters:
        target - the object to control
        context - the relevant context

      • getNext

        public TweenController getNext()
        Gets the next link in the chain, or null if no chain is set.
        Returns:
        the next link in the chain

      • interpolate

        protected abstract void interpolate(GObject target,
                                    Context context,
                                    double percentage)
        Interpolates the tween for the given value.
        Parameters:
        target - the object to control
        context - the relevant context
        percentage - the percentage of completion of the tween

      • setNext

        public void setNext(TweenController next)
        Sets the next link in the chain. To add to the end of the chain easily, use the chain(TweenController) method. Passing null will have the same effect as calling unchain().
        Parameters:
        next - the new next link

      • unchain

        public void unchain()
        Removes the chain from this controller. This will not break the rest of the chain. For example, if a is chained to b and b is chained to c, calling a.unchain() will leave b chained to c.

        This method is identical to setChainStart(null).

      • with

        public void with(java.util.List<TweenController> tweens)
        Calls with(TweenController) on all given items. This sets each given tween to start with this tween. That is, when this tween starts, the other tweens will start as well.
        Parameters:
        tweens - a list of tween that should start with this tween

      • with

        public void with(TweenController tween)
        Sets the given tween to start with this tween. That is, when this tween starts, the other tween will start as well.
        Parameters:
        tween - a tween that should start with this tween

      • with

        public void with(TweenController... tweens)
        Calls with(TweenController) on all the given items. This sets each given tween to start with this tween. That is, when this tween starts, the other tweens will start as well.
        Parameters:
        tweens - an array of tweens that should start with this tween
